Childhood Health Assessment Questionnaire cited 26-Oct-2016 https://www.niehs.nih.gov/research/resources/assets/docs/chaq_instructions_508.pdf
Childhood Health Assessment Questionnaire cited 26-Oct-2016 http://www.badbir.org/Website%20data/Ethical%20Approval/Amendment8/12.%20CHAQ%20form.pdf
Hildegard Franke, freshEHR Clinical Informatics Ltd.<hildi@freshehr.com>

details.purpose: For the recording of details of the Childhood Health Assessment Questionnaire used to assess how a child's arthritis affects his or her ability to function in daily life.
details.use:
To record the details of the Childhood Health Assessment Questionnaire used in Rare Diseases management settings to assess how a child's arthritis affects his or her ability to function in daily life.
The questionnaire is completed by parents or carers of the child, and it is intended that the person completing the questionnaire checks the one response which best describes the child's usual activities (averaged over an entire day) OVER THE PAST WEEK. It is also intended that only those difficulties or limitations are noted which are due to illness. If most children at the child's age are not expected to do a certain activity, the responder should mark it as "Not Applicable". For example, if the child has difficulty in doing a certain activity or is unable to do it because he/she is too young but not because he/she is RESTRICTED BY ILLNESS, the activity should be marked as "NOT Applicable".

items.items: The Childhood Health Assessment Questionnaire for arthritis.
A specific date and/or time which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Assessment of child's ability to dress, including tying shoelaces and doing buttons.
Assessment of the child's ability to shampoo his or her hair.
Assessment of the child's ability to remove socks.
Assessment of the child's ability to cut his or her fingernails.
Assessment of child's ability to perform functions related to dressing and grooming.
The child is able to dress without any difficulty.
The child is able to dress with some difficulty.
The child is able to dress with much difficulty.
The child is unable to dress.
The child is able to shampoo his or her hair without any difficulty.
The child is able to shampoo his or her hair with some difficulty.
The child is able to shampoo his or her hair with much difficulty.
The child is unable to shampoo his or her hair.
The child is able to remove socks without any difficulty.
The child is able to remove socks with some difficulty.
The child is able to remove socks with much difficulty.
The child is unable to remove socks.
The child is able to cut his or her fingernails without any difficulty.
The child is able to cut his or her fingernails with some difficulty.
The child is unable to cut his or her fingernails with much difficulty.
The child is unable to cut his or her fingernails.
Assessment of the child's ability to stand up from low chair or floor or get in and out of bed or stand up in a crib.
Assessment of child's ability to stand up from low chair or floor.
The child is able to stand up from low chair or floor without any difficulty.
The child is able to stand up from low chair or floor with some difficulty.
The child is able to stand up from low chair or floor with much difficulty.
The child is unable to stand up from low chair or floor.
Get in and out of bed or stand up in crib
Assessment of the child's ability to get in and out of bed or stand up in a crib.
The child is able to get in and out of bed or stand up in a crib without any difficulty.
The child is able to get in and out of bed or stand up in a crib with some difficulty.
The child is able to get in and out of bed or stand up in a crib with much difficulty.
The child is unable to get in and out of bed or stand up in a crib.
Assessment of the child's ability to perform functions related to eating.
Assessment of the child's ability to cut his or her own meat.
The child is able to cut his or her own meat without any difficulty.
The child is able to cut his or her own meat with some difficulty.
The child is able to cut his or her own meat with much difficulty.
The child is unable to cut his or her own meat.
Lift up cup or glass to mouth
Assessment of the child's ability to lift a cup or glass to mouth.
The child is able to lift a cup or glass to mouth without any difficulty.
The child is able to lift a cup or glass to mouth with some difficulty.
The child is able to lift a cup or glass to mouth with much difficulty.
The child is unable to lift a cup or glass to mouth.
Assessment of the child's ability to open a new cereal box.
The child is able to open a new cereal box without any difficulty.
The child is able to open a new cereal box with some difficulty.
The child is able to open a new cereal box with much difficulty.
The child is unable to open a new cereal box.
Assessment of the child's ability to perform functions related to walking.
Assessment of the child's ability to walk outdoors on flat ground.
The child is able to walk outdoors on flat ground without any difficulty.
The child is able to walk outdoors on flat ground with some difficulty.
The child is able to walk outdoors on flat ground with much difficulty.
The child is unable to walk outdoors on flat ground.
Assessment of the child's ability to climb up five steps.
The child is able to climb up five steps without any difficulty.
The child is able to climb up five steps with some difficulty.
The child is able to climb up five steps with much difficulty.
The child is unable to climb up five steps.
Statement about the aids or devices usually used by the child for dressing, grooming, arising, eating and walking.
The child usually uses a cane.
The child usually uses a walker.
The child usually uses a wheelchair.
The child usually using devices used dor dressing, such as button hook, zipper pull, long-handled shoe horn,etc.
Built up pencil or special utensils
The child usually uses a built up pencil or special utensils.
The child usually uses a special or built-up chair.
Statement of which activity categories (dressing and grooming, arising, eating and walking) usually require help for the child from another person because of the child's illness.
The child usually needs help from another person for dressing and grooming because of his or her illness.
The child usually needs help from another person for arising because of his or her illness.
The child usually needs help from another person for eating because of his or her illness.
The child usually needs help from another person for walking because of his or her illness.
Assessment of the child's ability to perform functions related to hygiene.
Assessment of the child's ability to wash and dry entire body.
The child is able to wash and dry his or her entire body without any difficulty.
The child is able to wash and dry his or her entire body with some difficulty.
The child is able to wash and dry his or her entire body with much difficulty.
The child is unable to wash and dry his or her entire body.
Assessment of the child's ability to take a tub bath including getting in and out of the tub).
The child is able to take a tub bath without any difficulty.
The child is able to take a tub bath with some difficulty.
Get on and off toilet or potty chair
Assessment of the child's ability to get on and off the toilet or potty chair.
The child is able to take a tub bath with much difficulty.
The child is unable to take a tub bath.
Assessment of the child's ability to brush his or her teeth.
The child is able to get on and off toilet or potty chair without any difficulty.
The child is able to get on and off toilet or potty chair with some difficulty.
The child is able to get on and off toilet or potty chair with much difficulty.
The child is unable to get on and off toilet or potty chair.
The child is able to brush his or her teeth without any difficulty.
The child is able to brush his or her teeth with some difficulty.
The child is able to brush his or her teeth with much difficulty.
The child is unable to brush his or her teeth.
Assessment of the child's ability to comb or brush his or her hair.
The child is able to comb or brush his or her hair without any difficulty.
The child is able to comb or brush his or her hair with some difficulty.
The child is able to comb or brush his or her hair with much difficulty.
The child is unable to comb or brush his or her hair.
Assessment of the child's ability to perform functions related to reaching.
Reach and get down heavy object
Assessment of the child's ability to reach and get down a heavy object such as a large game or books from just above his/her head.
The child is able to reach and get down a heavy object such as a large game or books from just above his/her head without any difficulty.
The child is able to reach and get down a heavy object such as a large game or books from just above his/her head with some difficulty.
The child is able to reach and get down a heavy object such as a large game or books from just above his/her head with much difficulty.
The child is unable to reach and get down a heavy object such as a large game or books from just above his/her head.
Assessment of the child's ability to bend down to pick up clothing or a piece of paper from the floor.
The child is able to bend down to pick up clothing or a piece of paper from the floor without any difficulty.
The child is able to bend down to pick up clothing or a piece of paper from the floor with some difficulty.
The child is able to bend down to pick up clothing or a piece of paper from the floor with much difficulty.
The child is unable to bend down to pick up clothing or a piece of paper from the floor.
Assessment of the child's ability to pull on a sweater over his or her head.
The child is able to pull on a sweater over his or her head without any difficulty.
The child is able to pull on a sweater over his or her head with some difficulty.
The child is able to pull on a sweater over his or her head with much difficulty.
The child is unable to pull on a sweater over his or her head.
Assessment of the child's ability to turn his or her neck to look back over his or her shoulder.
The child is able to turn his or her neck to look back over his or her shoulder without any difficulty.
The child is able to turn his or her neck to look back over his or her shoulder with some difficulty.
The child is able to turn his or her neck to look back over his or her shoulder with much difficulty.
The child is unable to turn his or her neck to look back over his or her shoulder.
Assessment of the child's ability to perform functions related to gripping.
Assessment of the child's ability to write or scribble with a pen or pencil.
The child is able to write or scribble with a pen or pencil without any difficulty.
The child is able to write or scribble with a pen or pencil with some difficulty.
The child is able to write or scribble with a pen or pencil with much difficulty.
The child is unable to write or scribble with a pen or pencil.
Assessment of the child's ability to open car doors.
The child is able to open car doors without any difficulty.
The child is able to open car doors with some difficulty.
The child is able to open car doors with much difficulty.
The child is unable to open car doors.
Assessment of child's ability to open jars that have been previously opened.
The child is able to open jars that have been previously opened without any difficulty.
The child is able to open jars that have been previously opened with some difficulty.
The child is able to open jars that have been previously opened with much difficulty.
The child is unable to open jars that have been previously opened.
Assessment of child's ability to turn faucets on and off.
The child is able to turn faucets on and off without any difficulty.
The child is able to turn faucets on and off with some difficulty.
The child is able to turn faucets on and off with much difficulty.
The child is unable to turn faucets on and off.
Assessment of the child's ability to push open a door when he or she has to turn a door knob.
The child is able to push open a door when he or she has to turn a door knob without any difficulty.
The child is able to push open a door when he or she has to turn a door knob with some difficulty.
The child is able to push open a door when he or she has to turn a door knob with much difficulty.
The child is unable to push open a door when he or she has to turn a door knob.
Assessment of the child's ability to perform general activities.
Assessment of the child's ability to run errands and shop.
The child is able to run errands and shop without any difficulty.
Get in and out of car
Assessment of the child's ability to get in and out of a car, toy car or school bus.
The child is able to run errands and shop with some difficulty.
The child is able to run errands and shop with much difficulty.
The child is unable to run errands and shop.
The child is able to get in and out of car, toy car or school bus without any difficulty.
The child is able to get in and out of car, toy car or school bus with some difficulty.
The child is able to get in and out of car, toy car or school bus with much difficulty.
The child is unable to get in and out of car, toy car or school bus.
Assessment of the child's ability to ride a bike or tricycle.
The child is able to ride a bike or tricycle without any difficulty.
The child is able to ride a bike or tricycle with some difficulty.
The child is able to ride a bike or tricycle with much difficulty.
The child is unable to ride a bike or tricycle.
Assessment of the child's ability to do household chores (e.g. wash dishes, take out trash, vacuuming, yardwork, make bed, clean room).
The child is able to do household chores without any difficulty.
The child is able to do household chores with some difficulty.
The child is able to do household chores with much difficulty.
The child is unable to do household chores.
Assessment of the child's ability to run and play.
The child is able to run and play without any difficulty.
The child is able to run and play with some difficulty.
The child is able to run and play with much difficulty.
The child is unable to run and play.
Statement about the aids or devices usually used by the child for hygiene, reach, grip and activities.
The child usually uses a raised toilet seat.
The child usually uses a bathtub seat.
The child usually uses a jar opener for jars that have been previously opened.
The child usually uses a bathtub bar.
The child usually uses long-handled appliances for reach.
The child usually uses long-handled appliances in the bathroom.
Statement of which activity categories (hygiene, reach, gripping and opening and errands and chores) usually require help for the child from another person because of the child's illness.
The child usually needs help from another person for hygiene because of his or her illness.
The child usually needs help from another person for reaching because of his or her illness.
The child usually needs help from another person for gripping and opening things because of his or her illness.
The child usually needs help from another person for errands and chores because of his or her illness.
Rating of how much pain the child has had because of his/her illness in the past week on a scale of 0 (no pain) to 100 (very severe pain).
Rating of how child is doing, considering all the ways arthritis is affecting him or her, on a scale of 0 (very well) to 100 (very poor).
Record any issues or factors that may impact on the questionnaire answers.
Additional information required to capture local context or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
e.g. Local hospital departmental infomation or additional metadata to align with HL7 or CDISC equivalents.

Total score from the eight assessment categories, with the highest score in each category counting towards the total score. Use of devices always scores 2, but can be superceded by a 3 score in that category.
Calculated from the total score divided by the number of categories answered.
